p: As early as in 1978, it was shown that the complement system is necessary to protect mice from a lethal influenza infection [ 44]. In 1983, it was established that human serum contains antibodies capable of neutralizing the influenza virus by activating the classical complement pathway [ 45]. To date it is known that influenza virions can activate both the classical and alternative complement pathways, and that antibody opsonization is required for efficient lysis of virions [ 46].
